message_1: What is the bond energy of the carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bond in methane (CH4) given that the enthalpy change of combustion of methane is -890 kJ/mol and there are four C-H bonds in a methane molecule?
message_2:
To find the bond energy of a single C-H bond in methane, we can divide the total enthalpy change of combustion by the number of C-H bonds in a methane molecule.

Enthalpy change of combustion: -890 kJ/mol
Number of C-H bonds in methane: 4

Bond energy of a single C-H bond = (-890 kJ/mol) / 4

Bond energy of a single C-H bond = -222.5 kJ/mol

The bond energy of a single carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bond in methane is approximately -222.5 kJ/mol. Note that the negative sign indicates that energy is released when the bond is formed.
